terms.definition: Count of protons in the nucleus. Defines the element.
Total number of protons and neutrons in a specific nuclide.
In particle physics, a subatomic particle that follows Fermi–Dirac statistics. Fermions have a half-integer spin (spin ⁠1/2⁠, spin ⁠3/2⁠, etc.) and obey the Pauli exclusion principle.
Weighted average of isotopic masses for a natural sample.
Amount containing 6.02214076×10^23 specified entities.

terms.types: Quark generations I, II and III.
terms.definition: In general, that class of particles that use to be positive or neutrally charged. t

terms.types: Lepton generations I, II and III.
terms.definition: In general, that class of particles that use to be negative or neutrally charged.
Temperature at which vapor pressure equals ambient pressure.
Ttype of massless elementary particle that mediates the strong interaction between quarks, acting as the exchange particle for the interaction.
Temperature at which solid and liquid phases coexist at 1 atm.
Relative tendency of an atom to attract bonding electrons.
Elements in the middle of the table, groups from 3-12. Mostly transition metals. The d-block elements are all metals and most have one or more chemically active d-orbital electrons.

Known as well as the fundamental metals. These elements are generally not considered part of any group. They come in two series: lanthanum through ytterbium in period 6, and actinium through nobelium in period 7.

First elements predicted to begin by the atomic number 121. They are likely already low enough in energy to start participating chemically in element 121. The the g-block would have eighteen elements.
Energy change when an atom gains an electron to form an anion.
Energy required to remove the outermost electron from a gas-phase atom.
Half the distance between nuclei of two bonded identical atoms.
Mass per unit volume at specified conditions.
100,000 pascals (IUPAC standard state).
Horizontal row in the periodic table.
Vertical column in the periodic table.
d-block elements, typically with partially filled d subshells.
p-block metals with relatively high electronegativity and low melting points.
Elements with properties intermediate between metals and nonmetals.
Group 17 reactive nonmetals.
Group 18 largely inert gases at STP.
Elements 57–71, f-block rare earths.
Elements 89–103, f-block, many radioactive.
Parts per million by mass of an element in the crust.
